questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect:
questions.solution:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who do not have the disease, i.e. true negative.

Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease, i.e. true positive.

False-positive are those who don't have the disease but tested positive.

False-negative are those who have the disease but tested negative.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found to be positive for SARS-CoV-2. On contact tracing, 30 people have been identified as close contacts but none of them shows any symptoms or signs. What is the time duration for which they must be quarantined?
questions.solution:
Quarantine is the limitation in freedom of movement of healthy contacts of cases, who have been exposed for a period that lasts as long as the maximal incubation period of the disease.

It is a primary level of prevention and falls under specific protection measures. The various types of quarantine are:

  • Absolute - Complete limitation of movement
  • Modified - Selective partial limitation of movement
  • Segregation - Observation of a group of persons in a population after separation

Wrist drop is the earliest sign

The signs and symptoms of lead poisoning occur only when the blood lead levels exceed 70mcg/dL, which is known as the threshold phenomenon.

Lead poisoning is also known as plumbism/ Saturnism/ painter's colic.

questions.text: A case-control study was done among 500 lung cancer patients and 400 controls. The study groups had 400 and 50 smokers respectively. Calculate the odds ratio.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the odds ratio (OR) is 28.

The given data is represented as:

Disease  -

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of a randomised controlled trial?
questions.solution:
Before and after comparison studies are a type of non-randomized trials.

These are community trials and centre around comparing the incidence of disease before and after the introduction of a preventive measure. They are of two distinct types:

  • Before and after comparison studies without control.
  • Before and after comparison studies with control.

Non-randomized trials include:

  • Before and after comparison studies. 
  • Uncontrolled trials. 
  • Natural experiments.

questions.text: Which of the following disposal methods uses high temperature and dry oxidation?
questions.solution:
Incineration is a high-temperature dry oxidation process.

Waste that is incinerated need not undergo any type of pre-treatment. It helps to reduce weight as well as volume. The temperature in the incinerator is 800⁰C in the primary chamber and 1050⁰C in the secondary chamber.

Types of incinerators:

  • Rotary kilns
  • Single chamber pyrolytic
  • Double chamber pyrolytic

The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are:

Low-heat system High-heat system

Autoclaving: Uses steam. It is of two types-

  1. Gravity flow autoclave 
  2. Vacuum autoclave

Microwaving: Uses moist heat and steam generated by microwave energy

Incineration: Waste is destroyed/denatured under high temperatures 

Plasma pyrolysis: Waste is treated at high temperatures under controlled conditions to form gases that are subjected to combustion in the secondary chamber

Hydroclaving: The waste is subjected to indirect heating by applying steam to the outer jacket

Dry heat sterilization: Waste sharps are treated using dry heat at a temperature >185 C for 150 minutes

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anemia. Which of the following is incorrect about the epidemiology of this disease?

choices.text: It is prevalent in areas with high frequency of malaria
It is an autosomal dominant disorder
Couples at risk can undergo prenatal testing and diagnosis
It manifests during the first year of life

questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows sickling of RBCs, suggestive of sickle cell anemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. 

The prevalence is high among Africans. This disorder usually has its onset during the first year of life. Couples at risk can opt for prenatal testing and diagnosis as well.

questions.text: A district in Andhra Pradesh reported severe drought. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you expect to see in this population?
questions.solution: Vitamin A deficiency is the most common deficiency in areas of famines and droughts. It leads to xerophthalmia and blindness.

questions.text: What mode of prevention is disability prevention by appropriate treatment an example of?
questions.solution:
Disability prevention by appropriate treatment is an example of secondary prevention. This is because disability has not occurred yet so correct treatment can stop it from developing.

After the disability has set in, prevention of progression of disability from transitioning into a handicap is tertiary prevention. It is also called disability limitation.

questions.text: For what purpose were knowledge, attitude, and practice (KAP) studies first used in India?
questions.solution:
Knowledge, attitude and practice (KAP) studies were first used in India to study family planning.

These studies help in evaluating the knowledge, attitude, and practices of a community. It also gives an educational diagnosis.

questions.text: All of the following are true about socialized medicine except:

choices.text: Ensures social equity and universal coverage
Use state funds for free medicine

questions.solution:
Increasing the utilization of health services is not a component of socialized medicine.

It refers to the provision of medical service through the state funds; however, it is operated and regulated by professional groups. Russia was the first to completely socialize medicine.

It eliminates competition among physicians as well as ensures social equity and universal health coverage.

questions.text: A new drug was approved for the treatment of prostate cancer. It has been shown to prevent early deaths but not cure the cancer. What is expected to happen to the cases of prostate cancer over a period of time?

choices.text: Increase in incidence, no change in prevalence
Decrease in incidence, increase in prevalence
Increase in incidence, decrease in prevalence
Increase in prevalence, no change in incidence

questions.solution:
A new drug that prevents death yet does not cure the disease will cause an increase in prevalence but the incidence remains the same.

In the given scenario, the drug reduces early deaths but does not cure prostate cancer. Hence, there is a paradoxical increase in the prevalence while the incidence remains the same.

Prevalence depends on two factors, the incidence and duration of illness. If the population is stable and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as:

P = I X D

(I - Incidence and D - Mean duration)

This equation shows longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Note:

  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Following an outbreak of a disease, you are asked to calculate the secondary attack rate (SAR). What is the denominator you would use?

choices.text: All people having history of contact with a case
All people susceptible in the entire area
All the people in contact with the primary case
All the close or exposed contacts those are susceptible

questions.solution:
The denominator used for calculating SAR is all the close or exposed contacts that are susceptible.

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period.

It is calculated by the formula:

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)

Primary cases are usually excluded from the numerator and denominator.

Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

questions.text: In which model of health education does internalization occur?
questions.solution:
Internalization belongs to the motivation model.

There are three models of health education:

  • Medical model: transfer of proven medical information into education. It does not bridge the gap between knowledge and behavior.
  • Motivation model: creates awareness of health needs and problems. Awareness leads to motivation which includes stages of interest, evaluation, and decision-making. It is followed by acceptance of the new idea which becomes part of his existing values, known as internalization.
  • Social intervention model: focuses on changing the social environment which subsequently shapes the behavior of individual and the community.

questions.text: Which of the following factors in a study will cause Berkesonian bias?

choices.text: Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects
Different rates of hospital admission of different diseases
Researcher's belief in the treatment changing the outcome of the study
Cases that are lost to follow-up

questions.solution:
Berkesonian bias occurs due to the different rates of hospital admission of people with different diseases. It is a type of selection bias termed after Joseph Berkeson who described it.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

  • Planet
  • Prosperity
  • Peace
  • Partnership

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about systematic reviews?
questions.solution:
Meta-analysis is not always performed in systematic reviews.

A systematic review is the process of locating and synthesizing the research on a particular question using organized, transparent, and replicable procedures. It ranks high in the hierarchy of evidence in medicine.

Steps of a systematic review:

  • The research question is formulated. It is always focused.
  • The literature on studies is always found and appraised after criteria of eligibility are established.
  • Meta-analysis is usually done in a systematic review for quantification but it is not compulsory.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a socio-economic determinant of health?
questions.solution:
Lifestyle is a behavioural and socio-cultural determinant of health. It is not a socio-economic determinant.

Socio-economic determinants of health are the following:

  • Economic status (per capita GNP)
  • Education
  • Occupation
  • Political system  

Lifestyle is simply the way people live. It reflects our social values, attitudes, and activities. It is composed of: 

  • Cultural patterns (daily nutrition, superstitions)
  • Behavioral patterns (personal hygiene, sedentary life)
  • Lifelong personal habits (e.g. smoking, alcoholism) 

Lifestyle is learned by social interaction with parents, siblings, friends, school, and mass media.  

Our political system determines our health. It can help shape community health services with regards to resource allocation, manpower policy, choice of technology, and the degree to which these services are made available & accessible to all segments of the society.

The percentage of GDP spent on health is an indicator of political commitment. WHO recommends at least 5% of GDP to be spent on health care. India spends about 2.1 % of its GDP on health(budget 2022-23).

questions.solution: Comprehensive health care as stated by the Bhore committee means giving integrated preventive, curative, and promotional health care to every individual, irrespective of their ability to pay.

questions.text: Which of the following is a silent epidemic?
questions.solution:
Alzheimer’s disease is referred to as the silent epidemic of the century.

Nearly 50 million people globally are living with this disease. Since it strikes so often, so arbitrarily, and with such little warning, many have dubbed it the silent epidemic.

questions.text: What is Sullivan's index?

choices.text: Years of life lost due to premature death

questions.solution:
Sullivan's index measures life expectancy free from disability. Sullivan's index = Life expectancy - Years of disability

It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current pattern of mortality and disability continues to apply.

It is also called disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) and active life expectancy. It doesn’t take into account premature death.

questions.text: In a village of 5000 people, an outbreak of cholera led to 200 cases with 50 deaths. What is the case fatality rate?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate is 25%.

Case fatality rate: (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100

                         : 50/200 * 100 = 25%

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Measures in sentinel surveillance do not aim at identifying:
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance does not include identifying cases free of disability.

Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases, in addition to the already existing and new cases. It is used for supplementing routine notifications.

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: While studying a disease, you find that it affects both humans and lower vertebrates and can be transmitted in either direction. How would you classify this disease?
questions.solution:
A disease that affects both humans and lower vertebrates and which can be transmitted in either direction is classified as amphixenosis. E.g, Trypanosoma cruzi and Schistosoma japonicum.

It is a type of zoonoses. Zoonoses are diseases that are transmitted between vertebrate animals and humans.

Other types of zoonoses include:            

  • Anthropozoonoses - infections that are transmitted to man from vertebrates. E.g., Rabies, plague etc.
  • Zooanthroponoses - infections that are transmitted to vertebrates from humans. E.g., Human tuberculosis in cattle.

Epizootic disease refers to an outbreak or epidemic of a disease in an animal population, often with the implication that it may also affect human populations. Enzootic disease is an endemic occurring in animals.

Note: Epornithic diseases are those diseases which are epidemic in bird populations. E.g., Psittacosis.

The test shows positive results on 180 of the patients with the disease and negative results on 150 of the patients without the disease. Which of the following is true?

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics:

  Common source, single exposure epidemic Common source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls <1 incubation period of a particular disease Extends >1 incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19.

Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point source, multiple exposure outbreak.

questions.text: In a population of 9000 people, 2100 are alcoholics. 70 alcoholics and 23 non-alcoholics developed cirrhosis. What is the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is 90%.

Number of people exposed (to alcohol) = 2100 
Number of people not exposed (to alcohol) = 6900 

Incidence of cirrhosis among exposed = 70/2100 (IExposed)
Incidence of cirrhosis among non-exposed = 23/6900 (INon-exposed)

Attributable risk (AR) = [ ( IExposed - INon-exposed) / IExposed ]*100
= [ (70/2100 - 23/6900) / (70/2100)] *100
= [ 9 / 10 ] *100
= 90

Thus, the attributable risk (AR) is 90%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text:
Which of the following toxins acts by inhibiting protein synthesis?

(ETEC - Enterotoxigenic E. coli)
questions.solution:
Shiga toxin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Shiga toxin or verotoxin is an exotoxin produced by Shigella species. It consists of two subunits A and B. The B subunit binds to globotriaosylceramide receptors on the target cell, and then, the A subunit gets internalized. The A subunit leads to inhibition of 60S ribosome, leading to shut down of protein synthesis. Its site of action is in the endothelial cells of small blood vessels of GIT.

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A shipyard worker is diagnosed with asbestosis. Which of the following is false about his condition?

choices.text: The symptoms usually occur after 5-10 years of exposure
Peribronchial fibrosis is a characteristic finding
The most dangerous form of asbestos is chrysolite type

questions.solution:
Amphibole is the most dangerous form of asbestos. Chrysolite is a safer form of asbestos compared to amphibole.

Asbestosis is a pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. It progresses even after the removal of contact with asbestos. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.

Sputum shows asbestos bodies, which are asbestos fibers coated with fibrin. The image given below shows asbestos bodies:

The complications that can occur are:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis 
  • Carcinoma of the lung 
  • Mesothelioma of the pleura
  • Malignancy of the gastrointestinal tract

questions.text: While collecting surveillance data for disease X, you find that the incidence of the disease is zero in your region. Which of the following statements best describes this scenario?

choices.text: Disease is eliminated from the region.
Disease is well controlled in the region.
Disease is eradicated from the region.
Disease shows iceberg phenomenon in the region.

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, as the disease has zero incidence, we can say the disease has been eliminated from the region.

Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required.

Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required.

Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, latent, and undiagnosed cases. The clinical or diagnosed cases are represented by the floating tip of the iceberg and not the submerged portion. As disease incidence is zero here, there are no cases to form the iceberg.

questions.text: A new drug for multiple sclerosis is undergoing clinical trials where its therapeutic efficacy is being confirmed and adverse reactions are being monitored. Which of the following phases is the drug most likely in?
questions.solution:
The confirmation of therapeutic efficacy and monitoring of adverse reactions of a new drug happens in phase III of the clinical trial.

Purpose of phase III: 

  • Confirmation of the effectiveness of the drug in patients with the target disease
  • Monitoring of adverse reactions 

Phase II involves therapeutic exploration which is the evaluation of the efficacy of the drug and dose-ranging (determination of the optimum tolerated dose).

questions.text: What are the minimum and maximum values established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI?
questions.solution:
The minimum value established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI is 20 years and the maximum is 85 years.

These minimum and maximum values are used to calculate the dimension indices in HDI and are called goalposts.

Each dimension index is calculated using the formula:

Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value).

questions.text: A young woman with a family history of beta-thalassemia is planning to marry her first cousin. Which of the following will you recommend for this woman?
questions.solution:
This young woman must be advised to undergo prospective counseling.

It refers to the process explaining to heterozygous individuals the risk of having affected children if they marry another heterozygous individual. It is performed prior to conception.

Retrospective counseling is performed after the genetic disorder has already occurred in the first child.

questions.text: In which of the following states will the host not shed the infectious organism?
questions.solution:
The host does not shed the infectious organism in case of a latent infection. This is defined as a state in which the host does not show signs and symptoms of the disease and does not shed the organism.

It can be seen in conditions like herpes simplex, ancylostomiasis, infections due to slow viruses, Brill-Zinsser disease, etc.

Subclinical infection is a state where the host harbours the infectious agent without developing signs and symptoms but sheds the infectious agent. This state is seen in conditions like hepatitis A, rubella, mumps, etc.

Healthy carriers are those who had subclinical infections and later developed a carrier state without suffering from the overt disease. This state is seen in: (mnemonic: CM - DPT)

  • Cholera
  • Meningitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Polio
  • Typhoid

Convalescent carriers are those which shed the infectious agent during the convalescent phase/recovery phase. Such carriers are seen in diphtheria, typhoid, cholera, pertussis, etc.

questions.text: For which of the following purposes is age-specific death rates not used?

choices.text: Identifying specific age groups at risk
Comparison for different causes within the same population
Comparison between different sexes in relation to accidents
Comparison between different age groups in relation to accidents

questions.solution:
Sex-specific death rates are used for the comparison between sexes and not age-specific death rates.

Age-specific death rates are used for:

  • Comparison for different causes within the same population.
  • Comparison between different age groups in relation to a particular event.
  • Identifying specific age groups at risk.

questions.text: What are prevalence studies also known as?
questions.solution:
Cross-sectional studies help in obtaining the prevalence of a disease. Hence, they are also known as prevalence studies.

Cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is examined once at one point in time. It is more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute ones. They do not provide information on the natural history of disease or incidence and also do not establish the time sequence.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about mass media?

choices.text: It has increased influence only in below-average educated population
It gives greater support for concentrated programmes
Mass media alone is inadequate in changing human behavior
Mass media reaches the widest population

questions.solution:
The advantage of mass media includes that it has increased influence across all educational levels, especially in above-average educational level.

Mass media includes TV, newspaper, radio, etc.

  • Advantages:
    • It reaches people even in the most remote areas.
    • It gets public attention.
    • It has increased influence across all educational levels, especially in above-average educational level.
    • It gives greater support for concentrated programmes.
  • Disadvantages:
    • One-way communication
    • Impersonal method and no face-to-face contact
    • Mass media alone is inadequate in changing human behavior.
